section.title: Removing the "index.php" Part From URLs
section.para: You need mod_rewrite (or something similar for other web servers, such as ISAPI_Rewrite for Microsoft IIS) to get rid of the "index.php" part in incoming and generated URLs. Make sure mod_rewrite is enabled, and create a .htaccess file in your pub directory with the following contents:

para.programlisting:
# enable rewrite engine RewriteEngine On
RewriteBase /~dzuelke/_projects/agavi/trunk/samples/pub/ # e.g. RewriteBase /~dzuelke/_projects/agavi/trunk/samples/pub/ # usually just "/" if your application's pub dir is the document root
# if requested url does not exist (i.e. it's likely an agavi route), pass it as path info to index.php RewriteRule ^$ index.php/ [QSA,L] RewriteCond %{REQUEST_FILENAME} !-f RewriteCond %{REQUEST_FILENAME} !-d RewriteRule (.*) index.php/$1 [QSA,L]

important.para: If you are running Apache with PHP as CGI, you cannot rewrite to a PHP file and pass path info. In this case, we have to resort to a query parameter to pass the incoming path to Agavi. To do that, change the two rewrite rules to:
RewriteRule (.*) index.php?something=/$1 [QSA,L]Then, tell the WebRouting that you're using this rewrite method in factories.xml:

<routing class="AgaviWebRouting"> <parameters> <parameter name="path_info_parameter">something</parameter> </parameters> </routing>Of course, you are free to use whatever you prefer as the parameter name. It will not be set as a Request parameter, unless the user actually supplies a parameter with this name.

section.para: The important thing is that you use the external path to the pub directory as the RewriteBase, i.e. the path that you would have to enter in your web browser location bar to reach the index page. If the pub directory is the document root, then the RewriteBase is just /.

The RewriteCond is a condition that executes the following RewriteRule if the requested filename (that is the incoming URL already mapped to a filesystem name by Apache) does not exist. If the requested URL exists, for instance, when an image on the webserver is requested, Agavi won't be called. Otherwise, the framework is started and the given URL is handed to Agavi as so-called Path Info which the WebRouting will use to match a route.

If you use ISAPI_Rewrite or another plugin for IIS, you can't use the rewrite condition shown above since it's not supported. Instead, you should create a RewriteCond that checks if the incoming URL does not fall into a certain schema (e.g. doesn't begin with /images and /css so these don't get rewritten and handed to Agavi).
